utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The entire like cities of Richmond - that population is being brought into the United States, allowed into the United States every three or four months.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: So I lived in Wausau, Wisconsin, 40,000 people in Wausau. So two Wausau, Wisconsins a month came--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: 76,000 last month.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: --illegally into America. And what I - and hearing and the clips that you played, I find it fascinating that Democrats are trying to say, we don't want to put kids in cages and this is a race that's played by the administration--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --coming here.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: But the bottom line is, I thought what Nielsen said was really important that they're giving pregnancy tests to girls as young as 10 years old, because they know that women who come - young girls who come on that dangerous journey, they're raped, they're sexually assaulted, and they have to get pregnancy tests. If you care about kids set up a policy that doesn't incentivize--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Incentivize people--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: --the cartels and the parents to bring kids on that dangerous journey where they're sexually assaulted. If you care about kids, don't bring them.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: They're making a huge, huge mistake with what they're doing, because they know it's a - do you do not agree with me, they know this is a crisis? They know it's a crisis.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: Listen, absolutely. Can I say what that also gets me, they say we don't want barriers, we don't want walls, we want boots and technology. So we have a new Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers. We send our - Scott Walker, our former Governor sent our troops to the Southern border to give more support, more boots in the ground. Tony Evers pulls our boots off the ground. So it won't build barriers and won't send the boots and the technology as a radical liberal Governor of Wisconsin. That's how extreme these people are.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Democrats are open borders, yes or no?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: Open borders, absolutely. Can't stop.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I mean, they have to be. I mean, their responses were ludicrous. I mean, Obama has these fencing things to hold people for processing, what do they want, the kids to be thrown out on the street when they come here? What are you supposed to do? They're trying to find sponsors - kids - and place them in sponsor homes. And what do you do you have to - I don't know what else you could possibly do. Obama found that dilemma, and they didn't have any problem with.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: And it's temporary, they have no complaint about Obama. But all of a sudden Trump uses the same facilities and they go after the poor guy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: This is all they have race and that--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: That's why we're winning suburban women. They want border security, they want safety, and they know that Democrats--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And so its safety for Americans and safety for these kids--

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --who are being brought in this journey. Thank You, Congressman. Thanks so much. And back to the controversy surrounding Congresswoman Omar and her questionable anti-Semitic remarks. Here she is just last week saying, "Jews can't be trusted, because they have a split allegiance with Israel".

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN OMAR, D-MINN.
utterances.utterance: I want to talk about the political influence in this country that says it is OK for people to push for allegiance to a foreign country.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Joining me now is Brooke Goldstein, a Human Rights Lawyer and Founder and Executive Director of the Lawfare Project, and Osama Siblani, Publisher of The Arab American News Osama how is that comment not anti-Semitic? The classic dual loyalty troop, how do you defend that?

utterances.speaker: OSAMA SIBLANI, PUBLISHER, THE ARAB AMERICAN NEWS
utterances.utterance: Do you know how many times I've heard and my community have heard of dual loyalty here in our community that Muslims cannot be trusted? How many times we've been called, go back to your - where you came from, to your homeland. No one said that this is anti-Muslin--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Really who in Congress said that?

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: No one stood for our rights, no one said that this is - should not be said in America. We heard this--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. So, Osama you're saying that or you're equating what Omar said, a sitting Member of Congress, with some nut on the internet or something someone said who - offend the people all the time

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --they say terrible things all the time and that should be condemned--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: They are not on the Internet, they are not in the Congress, they are members of the Republican Party, they are very, very close in their ideology to the Nazis, that's what they are.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. So--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: I mean, let's not just shove this under the carpet.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. So we've established that because there is anti-Muslim bias, which I have no doubt there is--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: And there is that Jewish bias too.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. Let me say, I just want to understand where you are coming from, I really do. So you're saying because there's anti-Muslim bias. That what Omar is saying about Jewish dual loyalty should get a pass? Is that it?

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: No I don't think that should - but we should start the debate. There should be a debate. We should not stifle the debate in America. We should talk about - like, we talk about the Saudis, we talked about the Iranians, no one says that this is anti-Muslim.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: They are a Muslim nation. So when we talk about Israel, we should not be equating this to Judaism. Judaism has nothing to do with Israel. Israel is occupying Palestinian land and Palestinian people and we should be talking and debating about what is Israel doing--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, that's not what she is doing now.

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: --to the Palestinian people.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: When she - and let's Brooke get a chance to speak. Look, if that's what the debate is, that's a legitimate debate to have. And I think we have those debates a lot, especially on college campuses, because I've been to some of them, about what the role in peace process should be? Who stole what from whom, OK that's fine. I have a problem with the analogies of the Jews and money and the Jews want the money and it's all about the Benjamin's baby, which you think--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: I don't think that this is what you said. I don't think that this is what you said.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Hey, Osama give it a rest. OK. Give it a rest, because I - she - Brooke didn't interrupt you, so just let her speak and then you can speak. OK? so Brooke, I have a problem so with how this is going down, because it is stereotypical, and I don't think we should be engaged, as much as possible, in stereotyping.

utterances.speaker: BROOKE GOLDSTEIN, HUMAN RIGHTS ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: Right. And I think we all have to step back and take a look at the big picture here. The level of anti- Semitism that's being tolerated by the Democratic Party right now, I think, has risen to a level of a national emergency. We have a Foreign Relations Committee which is responsible for defining and executing the --- and shaping U.S. Foreign Policy. We have someone sitting on that Committee who is a racist, whose views are more aligned with Islamic Jihad, than they are with the U.S. Constitution. We have Democratic members of government who are campaigning with people like Linda Sarsour who is connected to the Palestinian Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a designated terrorist group. And now we have a Democratic Party, that's been hijacked to the extent that it cannot even pass a resolution condemning anti-Semitism without being forced to water it down and make it meaningless. Could you not imagine if they wanted to pass a resolution condemning racism against African-Americans and the Democratic said, we're not going to pass that unless the same resolution talks about crimes that blacks commit against whites?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But to - right. But to - Osama's point, is this - can this reach a point where you're stifling debate? I think that's what some are concerned about.

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: What people are doing right now--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --and if you don't want to stifle debate, you want to have an actual debate on points and issues, correct?

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: Well, actually what's happening in here--

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: Right. But--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: --the Republicans are using this--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Hold on, hold on.

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: Foreign policy is not an excuse to turn around and accuse Jews of dual loyalty. Very often--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: That's not what you said, that's not what you said.

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: I'm just criticizing Israel--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: You are--

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: --this is exactly what she said. She's is treating things like for example--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: --You're putting words in her mouth. That's not what Ilhan said.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well--

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: --"May, Allah awaken everyone to the evils of the Jewish state". That's something you hear in a sermon--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: That's not Ilhan said. You guys should stop putting words in her mouth.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: That's not her memories of government talk in United States.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Osama when she made the initial statement about it's all about the Benjamins and for the little of money--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: But that's not what she said. She did not say that Jews have a dual loyalty, she did not say that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: She said some okay members in the Congress--

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: That's she did.

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: --some members in the Congress they have dual loyalty, yes, they do.

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: So where is her loyalty? Where is her loyalty? Is her loyalty to the U.S. constitution?

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: They do. They do. There are people in the congress they have loyalty towards Israel - can I make a statement in here?

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: --protection under the law? Is that what your loyalty - she talks sounds more like an Islamic extremist--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: Can I, can I?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. One at a time.

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: Can I make a statement here that the Republicans is using anti- Semitism in order to blackmail the Democrats and that should not happen. You should not allow it. Republicans should not be using anti-Semitism in order to stifle the debate or to blackmail the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Osama, Nancy Pelosi condemned - it's all about the Benjamin's baby comment, OK.

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: Nancy Pelosi is a pro-Israel congresswoman.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --is she part of the conspiracy? So she is part of the conspiracy - the Jewish conspiracy, is that what you are, sounds like you are getting toward the same territory that Ilhan Omar--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: I don't believe that there is a Jewish conspiracy. I believe that there is a pro-Israeli conspiracy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, the--

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: What--

utterances.speaker: SIBLANI
utterances.utterance: The pro-Israel elements in our society are trying to silence the debate.

utterances.speaker: GOLDSTEIN
utterances.utterance: --and the Democrat can deny that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. We're going to - we got to continue this. I appreciate you guys both coming on - coming up, by the way. This singer R. Kelly, this explosive new interview that just came out, he's another victim - everybody's a victim here. Dr. Drew Pinsky joins me next exclusively. Stay there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Singer R. Kelly is speaking out for the first time since being arrested and charged on 10 counts of felony, aggravated sexual abuse of young girls. He's been accused of everything from child pornography to running a sex cult over the past 25 years. But Kelly maintains his innocence and that he's the real victim. R. KELLY; AMERICAN SINGER-SONGWRITER: I didn't do this stuff. This is not me. I'm fighting for my (bleep) life. You're telling me what this (bleep). I can't - (bleep)

utterances.speaker: GAYLE KING, CBS NEWS REPORTER
utterances.utterance: Robert.

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: Are you all trying to kill me? You're killing me now. Y'all just don't want to believe the truth. You don't want to believe it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Joining me now exclusively is an old friend Drew Pinsky, an addiction specialist and doctor to the stars. Dr. Drew what do you make of that interview? He's obviously extremely emotional, explosive and I was worried about Gayle King for a moment there.

utterances.speaker: DR. DREW PINSKY, CELEBRITY DOCTOR
utterances.utterance: Yes. I'm - it's good to see Laura, by the way. And I got to tell you, this is - a lot of celebrities have been scrutinized lately. And this is the first time I've been frightened for him, for somebody. I'm fearful this guy could hurt himself. I mean, he really - his back is against the wall. He's financially in very serious trouble. He couldn't afford his bail. He couldn't afford child support. So today he was arrested on this. He can't have access to his children. He's being accused of very serious crimes. He is in big trouble and he is in desperate straits. So I'm actually worried about this guy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, does it seem to some extent - can you tell, I mean, it's difficult - it almost seems like it's like an ongoing reality show drama. The standing up, hitting your chest - I mean it seems - it seems choreographed a little bit. I mean, if I had to - I'm not an expert you are. But that's just a layman's view.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Well, what you're looking at is you're thinking to yourself, I think you don't protest too much, right? It's like, real too much, it's excessive, doesn't mean he did that. We just don't know. We can't know for sure. I mean, look, we're looking at a lot - we are looking at lot of celebrities' life with a new lens. I feel like we've all woken up from the slumber of the 70s when anything goes - I mean look at some of the lyrics from music from that era, they're talking about 14 year olds half the time. You know all of a sudden we've begun to scrutinize these people that we have idolized, merely because of their music or their appearance on television or movies, and it is - it has been seductive and it is ridiculous. We're looking at things very realistically now. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, he talked about what the parents of the girls - the alleged victims, their role in all of this. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: GAYLE KING, CBS NEWS REPORTER
utterances.utterance: Azriel Clary, what can you tell - what is your relationship with her? R. KELLY; AMERICAN SINGER-SONGWRITER: Right now? I'm seeing her. She is 21, I'm seeing her.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.utterance: She is 21?

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.utterance: But did you start seeing het at 17?

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: Absolutely not.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.utterance: Did you have sex with her when she was 17?

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: Absolutely, not. Absolutely, not. Although, her parents wanted me to--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Again, Dr. Drew, I mean, could that happen? I guess, it could if parents--

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Well, you must have seen the--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --wanted money, I guess.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: You must not have seen the Michael - you must not have seen the Michael Jackson leaving Neverland documentary, where - whether or not those allegations are true or not. You see how for somebody to be seduced - to seduce a young person, you have to seduce the entire family. And fame - we have such - we elevate people with fame to such a degree, we are easily seduced by it and it's possible. I don't know. We just don't know what has actually gone on. One of the things he did say, a couple things came - jump down to me about his interview that I thought we're very interesting. One is, he compartmentalized a lot. He talked about our R. Kelley vs. Robert and my understanding is he had some very serious trauma himself, and that's how people who are traumatized think. They compartmentalize the self and their emotions and that's sometimes how they carry out things that are not good. This compartmentalized piece of themselves is disavowed. That's not really me. I'm really Robert. And they can do some awful stuff and be a good person at the same time. That's one thing that jumped out at me in this particular interview. There seemed to be a good deal of compartmentalization. The other thing is something that I see celebrities do all the time which is the name they use out in the world, R. Kelly, again, versus Robert, it's not just compartmentalization. The thing you know of as the celebrity, they distance themselves from, as though that's just a cartoon character, so when people criticize that celebrity, R. Kelly, the it doesn't get to me, Robert.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Dr. Drew, I also want to get your thoughts on another big story you mentioned, the issue with Michael Jackson. And HBO is out with this new documentary about M.J. called "Leaving Neverland." And it details years the superstar allegedly abused two young boys. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: There's no thoughts of this is wrong or anything like that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: He told me if they ever found out what we were doing, he and I would go to jail for the rest of our lives.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Dr. Drew, why is this coming out now? I mean, it was -- he was on trial. He won, he had settlements. He's dead. What's going on here?

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: We don't know these guys, we don't know if the allegations are true or not. But I will tell you the documentary shows, again, the grooming process, precisely how it happens. If you saw Oprah's interview after the "Leaving Neverland" second part, she talks about that, how this is a really important for people to understand, that it's something people are drawn into. It's not painful and it's not an attack. It's a grooming process. And by the same token, because they loved that celebrity, they loved Michael Jackson, they wanted to protect them, they had all these ambivalent feelings that when they really woke up to what he had been doing to them, there was a flood of emotions and then there was a desire to talk about it. So the theory here, if these allegations are true, is they finally got enough distance. And in fact in both men's' case, it was the fact that they had children that they started to look at the child and go, oh, my God, something did something to me when I was young. This unbelievable, and that's where the emotional flood broke through. And somebody chose to tell the story, whether it's true or not.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Again, he's obviously not around to defend himself. None of us knows if it's true or false. But that's the difficulty with doing --

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Like I said, I just think we are waking up from a slumber. I really do. I really believe that we are waking up from a slumber from the '70s. I've been saying this -- all the years I was on "Love Line," I kept saying there is horrible things going on and we were accepting it. When you look at the pictures of Michael Jackson running around of the kids, you go, oh, my God. We were all groomed into accepting that. We have been through a period of history where a lot of things were acceptable that were not acceptable. And I think we are just waking up to that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think a lot of things are still acceptable -- I disagree. I think there's a lot of stuff that is pushing the envelope in family hour TV. That's all out the window.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Agreed. But we are waking up.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think on some of this stuff, but I think the envelope is pushed. Watch some of the award shows, the way people --

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: No, you're absolutely correct. You're correct. I don't disagree with you at all, but there is stuff we are waking up to as though we have been in some kind of weird slumber. Just look at the lyrics of songs from the '70s sometime and think about what some of these rock stars were doing with young children, and people are like oh, they are rock stars. What are we supposed to do? Well, we are waking up.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Michael Jackson actually responded to some of these allegations in an interview on "60 Minutes" back in 2009 with Ed Bradley. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL JACKSON, SINGER
utterances.utterance: If I would hurt a child, I would slit my wrists. I would never hurt a child.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Do you still think that it's acceptable to share your bed with children?

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.utterance: Of course. Of course. Why not?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He went on to say as long as it's platonic. And that was in 2003, by the way.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no. Nothing OK about it. I don't care who the 30- year-old man is, no. I don't care who he is. I don't care if half of his brain tissue is gone, no, no, no. That is not OK. If you read and watch the documentary, the kids talk about how they would go to toy stories and load baskets full of toys and run out. You would not let that happen as a parent. Your job is to teach kids how to get effectively into the world. And guess what, the world can be a very frustrating place. You don't get what you want all the time. Just that very -- just going to the toy store has me jumping out of my skin.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Again, where were the parents? It's the same question, where were the parents?

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: Seduced. They were seduced.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Everybody is seduced by the fame. Dr. Drew, it's great to see you. It's great to have you on tonight.

utterances.speaker: PINSKY
utterances.utterance: You, as well. Thank you, I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Up next, Will Smith facing backlash for, get this, not being black enough for a new role. And wait until you see how a CNN panel reacted to a new Democrat star? Raymond Arroyo breaks it all down in this week's "Seen and Unseen," next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's time for our "Seen and Unseen" segment, where we expose the big cultural stories of the day. Will Smith is under fire for not being black enough for Hollywood, and CNN features a Democratic star. Joining us now with all the details, Raymond Arroyo, FOX News contributor, "New York Times" bestselling author of the brand new book, "Will Wilder and The Amulet of Power." Congrats on that, Raymond.

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What is happening with Will Smith?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Will Smith, this might be -- we should have called this segment "Heard and Unheard" because I've got a little voice. This is what happens when you ride too hard in the floats with Ingraham.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That's a Mardi Gras joke.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Will Smith can't get a break where color is concerned, Laura. A few weeks ago, social media exploded over his role in "Aladdin." Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You really don't know who I am? Genie, wishes, lamp, none of that ringing a bell?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: They said he was too blue.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Too blue?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Too blue. Now Smith has been cast to play Richard Williams, the father of Serena and Venus Williams, in a new biopic called "King Richard." Even prominent figures have taken to Twitter claiming Will Smith is not black enough to play the role. Clarence Hill wrote "Colorism matters. Love Will Smith, but there are other black actors for this role." George M. Johnson, "Just like Chadwick shouldn't have played Thurgood Marshall, Will should not play Richard. Skin color matters in how folks are to treated and navigated spaces. Is Alexandria Shipp playing Venus?" Laura, I have a huge problem with this. It is constricting creative freedom and expression of artists, actors. They should be up in arms over this. In fact, I'm going to put up a picture of Will Smith. This is he and Dr. Bennet Omalu. This is a doctor he played in the movie "Concussion."

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Which was a great movie.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: You'll see Smith is much lighter than Dr. Omalu. Who cares? And by the way, Omalu loved Smith's performance. Chadwick Boseman played Jackie Robinson. Notice anything different? As you can see, he's actually a little darker than Jackie Robinson. Who cares?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Who care?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: But we are focusing on this. And the new rule is you cannot play a race not your own as an actor. That's horrible. When you have got Ben Kingsley winning Academy Awards for Gandhi, Laurence Olivier playing Othello in a career-defining role. We should be open to actors' ingenuity and creativity are not closing the doors on anybody, black white, light, dark, it doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I loved "Hamilton." I loved it.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And Lin-Manuel would not have been able to play that role because he's took dark for the role, right?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Or too white -- dark, white. But I don't know, you keep going down this road, it's going to be --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: We should be judged by the quality of our performances, not by the color of our skin.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And CNN this week convened a panel of voters who had voted for Hillary Clinton. When they were asked about Democratic upstart AOC, the panel went wild.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: She's a badass. I love her.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Wow. What a woman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: She is the candidate of the future.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: She has the Democratic Party nervous. She really personifies where we expect things to go.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Where we expect things to go.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Laura, whatever Ms. Cortez's social media skills, these voters are captivated by her image. One of them called her smart and intelligent. Listen to this.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRA OCASIO-CORTEZ, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: And if we work our butts off to make sure that we take back all three chambers of congress, rather, all three chambers of government, the presidency, the Senate, and the House --

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: The presidency, the Senate, and the House. I think she meant the Congress and the judiciary --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The chambers of government. Branches, chambers, that's a formality.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Who is paying attention?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No, that's a formality.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: They are wrapped up in her social media presence.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What does that tell you about branding?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: It's everything now. It's everything.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Branding. That's why you always say Republicans are woefully bad at storytelling. Even on the border issue today, Kirstjen Nielsen has these dramatic numbers at the border.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And she is presenting the facts, but the way you present them is also important, yes? It might have kind of set that up.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: As you can tell from our ashes, and you look like you did a drive- by.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The priest did a drive-by on me. He's like, get out of here.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I got the pastor's revenge. This is the biggest sinner in the world.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He really pressed down on you.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Today is Lent. People are giving up different things. Some churches are suggesting people give up plastic, plastic bags. I don't know why that would be. This is about subduing the flesh and conforming your will to God's. I don't know how giving up a plastic bag is going to get you there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I'm against plastic. You know I go to the beach and I pick up plastic. I'm like one of those craze old people.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Are you against floss? Do you floss your teeth?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes I do. I do like floss.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: That's plastic.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: There's too much plastic. But the priest today at mass said it's not about you. It's not about you. I'm giving up -- it's about your relationship with God.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Right, and what he sees.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And what you do after Lent.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to tell you what I'm giving up.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What are you giving up?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I'm giving up watching those R. Kelly interviews. Is this my camera? Is that my camera? Do I look stupid? Do I look stupid to you?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You've got to beat your chess. Then you'll fall over and they'll blame me for pushing you over.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: But Gayle King, she got it early.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Gayle King handled that really well.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: She was really good.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: She's a total pro.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Sit down, Robert. Sit down.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, Raymond, thanks so much. And stay there, because Hillary Clinton gets fact-checked on her racist allegations, the culture of victimology, and the socialism rising. Yes, a very special guest, renowned economist Tom Sowell is here next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, boohoo, Hillary Clinton seems to say she's not running in 2020, but she is running with the race card.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, D-FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I was the first person who ran for president without the protections of the Voting Rights Act, and I will tell you it makes a really big difference. It made a difference in Wisconsin where the best studies that have been done said somewhere between 40 and 80,000 people were turned away from the polls because of the color of their skin.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Guess what. "The Washington Post" gave her four Pinocchios for that blatant lie -- 80,000 people turned away from polls? Joining me now on this and so much more, renowned economist, old friend, Tom Sowell, senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, author of the phenomenal book, "Discrimination and Disparities," which is now out in a revised and enlarged edition. Tom, thanks for being here. Why is Hillary saying that? I think she knows it's not true. So why?

utterances.speaker: THOMAS SOWELL, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTE
utterances.utterance: Because she thinks it will get her some votes. That's the reason politicians say a lot of things and aren't true.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Hillary Clinton, so many others are now talking about reparations. Trump is a racist. It's race, race, race, race, race. Immigration policy is racist. The race word is the constant. It's like abortion and race in today's Democrat party.

utterances.speaker: SOWELL
utterances.utterance: It is. And I have a feeling that many Americans would just as soon not hear any more about race. But there are people for whom this is their ticket to whatever racket they are running, including the political racket. And it's tragic. What's tragic is that there are so many people out there who simply respond to words rather than ask themselves, is what this person says true? How can I check it? And so on.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Do you think that with that Jussie Smollett case in Chicago, and now we have this R. Kelly guy who was accused of -- R. Kelly is not focusing on race, but the Smollett case became one about race. And it was almost like there were certain people out there who were disappointed when it seemed like this thing with a big hoax. They wanted this to be a racial incident, a racial hate crime, reinforcing the stereotypes that this is what's wrong with society today, the overriding problem in society today is one of race, Tom.

utterances.speaker: SOWELL
utterances.utterance: Well, it's like in football. They are to run that play until someone finds a way to stop it. And as long as it pays off, they're going to keep doing it. What's painful to me is how few people there are today who bother to check out the facts. In many cases, just the smallest effort at checking out the facts would cause so many of these things to fall apart. And we have a whole history of this, going back to the Tawana Brawley woman back in the 19-somethings, and then the Duke Lacrosse case. So there have been any number of these things. But as long as they keep succeeding politically, they will continue to run that play.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Do you think President Trump would do well to make, like, monthly trips to underserved, more underprivileged areas, or to traditionally black colleges, communities of color, where he can just talk about why his policies are working, and why the economy is growing opportunities, jobs, greater employment, et cetera. Would you recommend that he do that?

utterances.speaker: SOWELL
utterances.utterance: I don't think that the venue matters that much. But there has to be some thoughtful notions about how free markets and other kinds of activities that are different from one are normally heard, how those things impact. And I don't see any sign of that of any significance unfortunately from the Republicans. I never cease to be amazed at how many opportunities they let go by. Right now, for example, Democrats around the country are lining up to stop charter schools from expanding, trying to cut back on them. And many of them are the very schools that are most successful, are the ones they are zeroing in on, places like Success Academy or KIPP Schools, and so forth. And the Democrats, I understand they have to do that because they are beholden to the teachers' unions. But why the Republicans don't say anything about it, that is what baffles me.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Truly pro-choice initiatives that actually help individuals instead of just focusing on blocks of individuals. Dr. Sowell, AOC, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, she has spoken a lot about socialism and being a Democrat Socialist. She is a young person, 28 years old. But she is representing a decent chunk of the Democrat Party today. I want to play something for you and have you react. Let's watch.

utterances.speaker: OCASIO-CORTEZ
utterances.utterance: When millennials talk about concepts like Democratic Socialism, we are not talking about these kinds of red scare bogeyman. We are talking about single-payer health care. We are talking about tuition free public colleges and universities. We are talking about a living wage. We are talking about guaranteed basic levels of dignity.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It sounds good to a lot of young people, and this focus group from CNN we just alluded to, and they seem very excited about these concepts. What are Republicans not doing?

utterances.speaker: SOWELL
utterances.utterance: The Republicans are not saying anything that I've heard. Of course, all these things sound wonderful. It's just that we now have more than half a century of knowledge, a track record of these kinds of ideas being put into practice in countries around the world and failing time and time again. Not merely failing, but making things worse than they were before. Venezuela is the classic case. And yet during the whole period when people are starving in Venezuela under socialism, the young people right out of our colleges are flocking to Bernie Sanders because they are judging by his words and how wonderful it sounds and not by what happens when you try to put those notions into practice, as has been tried again in countries in Europe, Asia, Africa, South America.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's failed everywhere. This is the worst repeat failed experiment we've ever seen. Dr. Tom Sowell, it is so great to see you tonight. Come back soon. Love your books.

utterances.speaker: SOWELL
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So many of my friends are texting me, saying tell them we are huge fans. All right, Dr. Sowell, thank you so much. We'll be right back with tonight's Last Bite.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The Last Bite. "Jeopardy." host Alex Trebek announced tonight that he has stage four pancreatic cancer. But he's still keeping the humor and the faith. ALEX TREBEK, "JEOPARDY." HOST: I have to host "Jeopardy." for three more years. So help me keep the faith, and we'll win. We'll get it done. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: We're praying for you tonight, Alex. And that's all the time we have tonight. Shannon and the "Fox News @ Night" team, take it from here. Shannon?
